articles.headline: Wanted: Skilled Workers for a Growing Economy in Brazil
articles.snippet: Many experts say the dearth of highly skilled labor, particularly engineers and tradesmen, will jeopardize Brazil’s economic and political rise.
articles.abstract: Many experts say the dearth of highly skilled labor, particularly engineers and tradesmen, will jeopardize Brazil’s economic and political rise.
articles.lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil  For almost any nation other than China or India, achieving more than 5 percent growth a year is hard. Doing it without skilled labor is even harder.

articles.headline: Car Sales at 10-Year Low
articles.snippet: Sales of new vehicles plunged in June, as high gas prices and a weak economy kept consumers away from showrooms.
articles.abstract: Sales of new vehicles plunged in June, as high gas prices and a weak economy kept consumers away from showrooms.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Sales of new cars and trucks plunged to their lowest level in more than a decade in June, as high gas prices and a weak economy kept American consumers away from dealer showrooms.

articles.headline: Judge Clears U.S. Request for UBS Clients’ Names
articles.snippet: A federal judge on Tuesday cleared the way for prosecutors to force the Swiss bank UBS to turn over the names of clients as part of an investigation of its offshore private banking practices.
articles.abstract: A federal judge on Tuesday cleared the way for prosecutors to force the Swiss bank UBS to turn over the names of clients as part of an investigation of its offshore private banking practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge cleared the way on Tuesday for prosecutors to force the Swiss banking giant UBS to turn over the names of wealthy clients as part of an investigation of its offshore private banking practices.
articles.byline: By Lynnley Browning and Julia Werdigier

articles.headline: Clay Felker, Magazine Pioneer, Dies at 82
articles.snippet: At New York magazine, Mr. Felker was credited with inventing a widely imitated formula for glossy weeklies.
articles.abstract: At New York magazine, Mr. Felker was credited with inventing a widely imitated formula for glossy weeklies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Clay Felker, a visionary editor who was widely credited with inventing the formula for the modern magazine, giving it energetic expression in a glossy weekly named for and devoted to the boisterous city that fascinated him  New York  died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82.

articles.headline: Obama Seeks Bigger Role for Religious Groups
articles.snippet: Barack Obama outlined a plan to expand federal spending on faith-based initiatives, a goal set by President Bush.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama outlined a plan to expand federal spending on faith-based initiatives, a goal set by President Bush.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZANESVILLE, Ohio  Senator Barack Obama said Tuesday that if elected president he would expand the delivery of social services through churches and other religious organizations, vowing to achieve a goal he said President Bush had fallen short on during his two terms.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Michael Luo

articles.headline: China Inspired Interrogations at Guantánamo
articles.snippet: An interrogation class at Guantánamo Bay was based on a 1957 study of Chinese Communist techniques used to obtain confessions, often false, from U.S. prisoners.
articles.abstract: An interrogation class at Guantánamo Bay was based on a 1957 study of Chinese Communist techniques used to obtain confessions, often false, from U.S. prisoners.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The military trainers who came to Guantánamo Bay in December 2002 based an entire interrogation class on a chart showing the effects of “coercive management techniques” for possible use on prisoners, including “sleep deprivation,” “prolonged constraint,” and “exposure.”

articles.headline: Stock Exchange’s Ex-Chief Wins Battle to Keep Pay
articles.snippet: Richard A. Grasso will keep the $139.5 million he was paid as the former New York Stock Exchange chief.
articles.abstract: Richard A. Grasso will keep the $139.5 million he was paid as the former New York Stock Exchange chief.
articles.lead_paragraph: For nearly five years, Richard A. Grasso was vilified for the riches he reaped while running the New York Stock Exchange.

articles.headline: Dispelling the Myths of Summer
articles.snippet: The current economic downturn has no one dominant mythology, and several are making the rounds. Many of these fictions will get good air time this summer.
articles.abstract: The current economic downturn has no one dominant mythology, and several are making the rounds. Many of these fictions will get good air time this summer.
articles.lead_paragraph: At some point over the last seven years, you have probably heard someone  a friend, a business executive, the president of the United States  say that the Sept. 11 attacks sent the American economy into a slump. It’s an understandable enough notion, given that the attacks occurred in 2001 and a recession began that same year.

articles.headline: Starbucks Announces It Will Close 600 Stores
articles.snippet: The company said Tuesday it would close 600 stores in the United States and lay off as many as 12,000 full- and part-time employees, the most in its history.
articles.abstract: The company said Tuesday it would close 600 stores in the United States and lay off as many as 12,000 full- and part-time employees, the most in its history.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a harsher economic climate, Starbucks’s green-and-white mermaid logo is about to become a little less ubiquitous.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Helmsley Left Dogs Billions in Her Will
articles.snippet: Leona Helmsley left instructions that a trust valued at $5 billion to $8 billion be used for the welfare of dogs.
articles.abstract: Leona Helmsley left instructions that a trust valued at $5 billion to $8 billion be used for the welfare of dogs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sure, the hotelier and real estate magnate Leona Helmsley left $12 million in her will to her dog, Trouble. But that, it turns out, is nothing much compared with what other dogs may receive from the charitable trust of Mrs. Helmsley, who died last August.

articles.headline: Deepening Cycle of Job Loss Seen Lasting Into ’09
articles.snippet: Experts say the troubles dogging the economy will be stubborn, leaving in place tight credit and scant job opportunities perhaps well into next year.
articles.abstract: Experts say the troubles dogging the economy will be stubborn, leaving in place tight credit and scant job opportunities perhaps well into next year.
articles.lead_paragraph: As automakers dropped their latest batch of awful sales numbers on the market on Tuesday, reinforcing the gloom spreading across the economy, the troubles confronting American workers seemed to intensify.

articles.headline: Moody’s Says Workers Rated Some Securities Incorrectly
articles.snippet: Already under scrutiny for its role in the credit crisis, the Moody’s Corporation said that some employees violated its code of conduct in rating some complex European securities.
articles.abstract: Already under scrutiny for its role in the credit crisis, the Moody’s Corporation said that some employees violated its code of conduct in rating some complex European securities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Already under intense scrutiny for its role in the credit crisis, the Moody’s Corporation said Tuesday that some employees had violated its code of conduct in rating complex European securities.
